awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Imaging small-scale convection and structure of the mantle in the south Pacific: a US contribution to an international PacificArray
awd_abstract_narration:
All deformation on the surface of Earth, including faulting responsible for earthquakes, is produced by the motion of tectonic plates.  It is widely accepted that thermal convection in the mantle drives plate motion, but details of that convection and how exactly it moves the plates are poorly understood.  Oceanic plates make up 70% of the Earth's surface and offer important windows into mantle convection, yet they are largely unexplored due to the lack of seismic data from the ocean basins.  Questions abound regarding the thermal structure of oceanic plates, the significance of volcanism in the middle of oceanic plates, and how the convecting mantle beneath the plates controls their movements. Waves in the gravity field and un-explained shallowing of the ocean floors hint at small-scale convection beneath the oceanic plates. This project contributes to an international effort to strategically place temporary arrays of instruments across the Pacific Ocean basin that record the energy from earthquakes. Recent community advances in ocean bottom seismographs will be used to record unique datasets in locations where large gaps in coverage exist today. These data will allow us to infer deformation and variations in mantle temperature related to small-scale convection.  As part of the international collaboration, all data will be openly available to scientists worldwide. The project supports the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

This project will collect 12-15 months of broadband ocean bottom seismograph (OBS) data in two 30-station arrays in the central and southern Pacific. These arrays, deployed at two distinct plate ages (~30 Ma and ~120 Ma), will address specific critical questions on the dynamics of the oceanic asthenosphere, including its underlying state (temperature, presence of melt, water or other volatiles, and deformation mechanism). The arrays are designed to image the anisotropic velocity signature of small-scale convection, which has been invoked to explain the flattening of the age versus depth curve in old ocean plates, 140-200 km wavelength gravity lineations, and ubiquitous off-axis, non-plume volcanism observed at a variety of scales. Anisotropic surface wave and body wave tomographic models will be supplemented by shear wave splitting and attenuation measurements to obtain a multi-faceted understanding of the asthenosphere and base of the plates. Finally, the order-of-magnitude increases in path coverage for surface and body waves in the south-central Pacific will enable new advances in global tomography.

por.por_cntn:
This project, named Pacific ORCA (OBS Research into Convecting Asthenosphere) substantially expanded our understanding of how oceanic tectonic plates work, how they mature, what lies beneath them, and how the overall process of plate tectonics operates in the oceans. 

A central aspect of this experiment was the deployment of two ocean-bottom seismic (OBS) arrays in the central (~40 million-year-old plate; "YoungORCA") and south-west (~90 million-year-old plate; "OldORCA") Pacific ocean basin. Each array comprised 30 high-quality instruments that recorded ground motion of the seafloor for approx. 1 year. Deployment and recovery of these arrays used ~130 days of ship time, provided by the UNOLS academic fleet, specifically the R/V Kilo Moana (3 cruises) and R/V Roger Revelle (1 cruise). The final recovery, in Nov-Dec 2020 took place during COVID, and required a huge logistical operation, including rigorous quarantine and sanitation protocols developed by the ship operators; a massive and laudable effort. During the four field campaigns, ~35 individual junior scientists were involved in the science parties from >20 institutions and >10 countries, and four early career scientists were trained as chief scientists. 

The valuable seismic datasets we obtained add to the sparse but growing suite of observations from the Pacific, a major plank of the US contribution to the international grassroots "Pacific Array of Arrays" initiative. The data, and our findings (below) have garnered significant international attention and discussion.

In addition to the primary dataset of seismic waveforms, we collected underway data now housed at the RollingDeck2Repository, conducted extensive multibeam mapping of previously unmapped seafloor, and dredged several sites to obtain seamount ages. 

The highlights of our scientific discoveries are as follows:

-       The first direct imaging of small scale convection beneath a young (42 Ma) oceanic plate 

-       Further imaging beneath an older (~90 Ma) oceanic plate that similarly shows large sub-plate wavespeed heterogeneity, implying that sub-plate convection may be a common process.

-       Imaging of elastic and dissipative properties within and beneath the plates that allow us to estimate the temperature, hydration, grain size, and melt content of the upper mantle

-       Imaging of the directional dependence of elastic properties within and beneath the plates that imply plates preserve fabrics inherited from mid-ocean ridge processes, but produce new fabrics beneath themselves in a heavily-sheared asthenospheric layer

-       An emerging understanding that the base of the oceanic lithosphere may be more or less unstable almost everywhere, with implications for plate maturation in general.

-       An emerging understanding that the oceanic asthenosphere may be more thin than previously recognized, and that it concentrates important processes that mediate ocean tectonics – it is low viscosity, low grain size, highly sheared, hot, melt-ridden, perhaps extra-hydrated, seismically slow, seismically attenuating, and roiling with small-scale convective cells. 

 

Additionally, this grant funded, and/or formed collaborative networks and projects that directly contributed to, the following:

-       A new, open-source tool for conducting acoustic ranging surveys to locate items on the seafloor, and an exploration of ideal survey patterns that will save days of future ship time.

-       A comprehensive investigation of OBS noise properties from a wide spectrum of deployments throughout the world’s oceans, with recommendations for future practitioners in designing OBS experiments

-       A study using OBS data to measure azimuthal anisotropy beneath the Juan De Fuca plate, shedding light on lithospheric maturation and asthenospheric flow systems proximal to a subduction zone

-       A study using machine learning to determine the shallow (upper 1 km of crust) elastic structure beneath OBS stations that have pressure gauges and vertical seismic channels.

-       A study allying dynamical modelling with seismological forward calculations to explore mantle conditions that permit sub-plate small scale convection and then interrogate how well synthetic models of this process match seismic observations. These models use the “latest and greatest” physics, including accounting for both dislocation and diffusion creep, and dynamically evolving grainsize (yielding key parameters for quantifying anelastic wave propagation effects).
